gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: Elemental selenium and particulate Acid-Volatile Sulfide from the U.S. GEOTRACES EPZT,EPZT_Redox_Elements projects of the U.S. GEOTRACES program

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Particulate Acid-Volatile Sulfide (pAVS) and elemental Selenium (pSe) depth profiles from McLane pump Dataset Description: <p>Data for the concentrations of&nbsp;Particulate Acid-Volatile Sulfide (pAVS)&nbsp;(0.8 mm) in depth profiles from in situ McLane pumps at GEOTRACES EPZT Stations 1-5, 7,&nbsp;9, 11, 13, 17, 18, 20, 21, and 23.</p><p><span style="font-size:11px"><strong>DMO notes:</strong></span></p><ul><li><span style="font-size:11px">changed -9999 values in SAMPNO to nd</span></li><li><span style="font-size:11px">added zeros to pad EVENT_LAT and EVENT_LON where decimal places were not 5 places like most of the dataset.</span></li><li><span style="font-size:11px">orginal name pAVS and&nbsp;pSe(0) changed to conform to GEOTRACES conventions</span></li></ul> Acquisition Description: <p>Samples analyzed for acid-volatile sulfides (AVS) were collected on McLane pumps suspended from a trace metal wire (Hytrel-jacketed Vectran). Pumps filtered for four hours, flowing first over a 51-µm polyester pre-filter, then over paired 0.8-µm pore-size, 142-mm Supor polyethersulfone filters. A small portion of the top Supor filter, representing ~2% of the filter area (0.8-51 µm size-fraction material), was sub-sectioned into polyethylene vials and frozen at -85˚C until shipboard AVS analysis, described below. Filter blanks were held within identical filter housings and submerged on one of the deeper pumps on each cast, but were not actively filtered through. Blanks were handled identically to samples during processing, which was conducted in a HEPA-filtered environment using trace metal procedures.</p><p>Particulate elemental samples were collected using McLane in situ pumps (P. Lam, UCSC) with splits (section) from a 0.8 µm Supor filter processed immediately in a N<sub>2</sub>-purged glove bag after collection and pump recovery; filter splits were placed and sealed in Tedlar bags and stored at -80°C until analysis. Particulate elemental selenium concentrations were determined using a sulfite leach following Velinsky and Cutter (1990) and analyzed like selenite+selenate following Cutter (1978).&nbsp; Precision was ca. 10% RSD (n=3).&nbsp;</p><p><strong>References:</strong>&nbsp;</p><p>Cutter, Gregory. "Species Determination of Selenium in Natural Waters." <em>Analytica Chimica Acta </em>98 (1978): 59-66.&nbsp;<a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0003-2670(01)83238-4" id="doi-value" style="box-sizing: inherit; color: rgb(49, 108, 157); text-decoration: none; background-color: transparent;" target="_blank" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier">doi:10.1016/S0003-2670(01)83238-4</a></p><p>Velinsky, D.J., and G.A. Cutter. "Determination of elemental selenium and pyrite-selenium in sediments." <em>Analytica Chimica Acta </em>235 (1990): 419-425. &nbsp;<a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0003-2670(00)82102-9" id="doi-value" style="box-sizing: inherit; color: rgb(49, 108, 157); text-decoration: none; background-color: transparent;" target="_blank" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier">doi:10.1016/S0003-2670(00)82102-9</a></p><p>&nbsp;</p>

gmd:keyword.gmx:Anchor: Eastern Tropical Pacific - Transect from Peru to Tahiti

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Access Constraints: none. Use Constraints: Please follow guidelines at: http://www.bco-dmo.org/terms-use Distribution liability: Under no circumstances shall BCO-DMO be liable for any direct, incidental, special, consequential, indirect, or punitive damages that result from the use of, or the inability to use, the materials in this data submission. If you are dissatisfied with any materials in this data submission your sole and exclusive remedy is to discontinue use.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: GEOTRACES is a SCOR sponsored program; and funding for program infrastructure development is provided by the U.S. National Science Foundation.GEOTRACES gained momentum following a special symposium, S02: Biogeochemical cycling of trace elements and isotopes in the ocean and applications to constrain contemporary marine processes (GEOSECS II), at a 2003 Goldschmidt meeting convened in Japan. The GEOSECS II acronym referred to the Geochemical Ocean Section Studies To determine full water column distributions of selected trace elements and isotopes, including their concentration, chemical speciation, and physical form, along a sufficient number of sections in each ocean basin to establish the principal relationships between these distributions and with more traditional hydrographic parameters;* To evaluate the sources, sinks, and internal cycling of these species and thereby characterize more completely the physical, chemical and biological processes regulating their distributions, and the sensitivity of these processes to global change; and* To understand the processes that control the concentrations of geochemical species used for proxies of the past environment, both in the water column and in the substrates that reflect the water column.GEOTRACES will be global in scope, consisting of ocean sections complemented by regional process studies. Sections and process studies will combine fieldwork, laboratory experiments and modelling. Beyond realizing the scientific objectives identified above, a natural outcome of this work will be to build a community of marine scientists who understand the processes regulating trace element cycles sufficiently well to exploit this knowledge reliably in future interdisciplinary studies.

gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: U.S. GEOTRACES East Pacific Zonal Transect

gmd:name.gmx:Anchor: U.S. GEOTRACES East Pacific Zonal Transect

gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: US GEOTRACES Pacific section: Characterizing the redox environment of the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean

gmd:name.gmx:Anchor: US GEOTRACES Pacific section: Characterizing the redox environment of the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The 2013 GEOTRACES Eastern Pacific Zonal Transect from Peru to Tahiti will cross an entensive oxygen deficient zone typically described as "suboxic"; however, measurements of sulfate reduction in this region suggest it may have some anoxic characteristics due to the presence of free sulfide. Redox conditions influence the solubility/stability of many trace elements which in turn affects their vertical and horizontal transport. A scientist from Old Dominion University plans to analyze water samples collected during the cruise for dissolved iodate/iodide, arsenic [As(III)/As(V)], selenium [Se(IV, VI), particulate Se(0), and nano- to picomolar hydrogen sulfide speciation (total, free/uncomplexed). These measurements, along with nitrate/nitrite, nitrous oxide, and iron species determined by other participants during the cruise, will be used to constrain the range of redox conditions within the oxygen deficient zone, assess the importance of in-situ reduction versus horizontal advection of the redox species, and the changing redox conditions within the hydrothermal plume of the East Pacific Rise. Availability of this data will also enable other researchers to determine the behavior of other redox sensitive trace elements in the ocean.
Eastern Tropical Pacific - Transect from Peru to Tahiti

Usual generation formula is ICES 4 character platform code then the cruise departure date in YYYYMDD format http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646297.rdf Name: SECT_ID Units: unitless Description: GEOTRACES cruise name. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646298.rdf Name: TIME_START_EVENT Units: unitless Description: Time at the start of the event according to the event log http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646299.rdf Name: DEPTH_MIN Units: meters Description: event depth minimum http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646300.rdf Name: DEPTH_MAX Units: meters Description: event depth maxium http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646301.rdf Name: depth_n Units: meters Description: nominal depth http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646302.rdf Name: AVS_TP_CONC_PUMP Units: picomoles per liter Description: particulate acid volatile sulfide http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646303.rdf Name: Se_0_TP_CONC_PUMP Units: nanomoles per liter Description: particulate elemental selenium http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/646305.rdf Name: EVENT_LON Units: decimal degrees Description: Longitude according to the event log; West is negative

PI-supplied Description: GEOTRACES event number.; General Description: event or operation number; often derived from date/time (MMDDHHmm) of sampling and when combined with year (YYYY) is a unique sampling identifier/data processing key. Date/time is not necessarily in GMT.
PI-supplied Description: Cast number.; General Description: cast or profile number
PI-supplied Description: Date at the start of the event, according to the event log.; General Description: date sampling starts such as YYYYMMDD

Format is YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.xxZ.; General Description: Date/Time (UTC) ISO formattedThis standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on any of the following forms:2009-08-30T09:05:00[.xx] (local time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]-05:00The dashes and the colons can be dropped.The T can also be dropped "by mutual agreement", but one needs the trailing Z if the time is UTC.Sample ISO_datetime_utc:2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)Format: YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS[.xx]Z (UTC time) NERC Description: String corresponding to format 'yyyy-mm-ddThh:mi:ss.sss' optionally terminated by 'Z'

PI-supplied Description: Latitude at the start of the event, according to the event log.; General Description: latitude, in decimal degrees, North is positive, negative denotes South; Reported in some datasets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance north or south from the equator, measured along the meridian of the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: GEOTRACES sample number.; General Description: unique sample identification or number; any combination of alpha numeric characters; precise definition is file dependent NERC Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers

PI-supplied Description: Bottle sample number, according to PI.; General Description: unique sample identification or number; any combination of alpha numeric characters; precise definition is file dependent NERC Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers
PI-supplied Description: Station number.; General Description: consecutive station number

PI-supplied Description: Used as a unique identifier for a cruise. Usual generation formula is ICES 4 character platform code then the cruise departure date in YYYYMDD format; General Description: Used as a unique identifier for a cruise. Usual generation formula is ICES 4 character platform code then the cruise departure date in YYYYMDD format. An underscore character may also be present.

PI-supplied Description: GEOTRACES cruise name.; General Description: The cruise_name is a local name chosen by project investigators for a research expedition on a vessel, as opposed to the formal/official cruise ID asserted by the vessel operator.
PI-supplied Description: Time at the start of the event according to the event log; General Description: starting time of observation, GMT time, 24 hour clock
PI-supplied Description: event depth minimum; General Description: minimum depth sampled
PI-supplied Description: event depth maxium; General Description: maximum depth sampled
PI-supplied Description: nominal depth; General Description: depth; nominal

PI-supplied Description: particulate acid volatile sulfide; General Description: Concentration of a trace element in seawater. Does not include trace metals and metaloids. Refer to dataset for element name and units.Periodic Table

PI-supplied Description: particulate elemental selenium; General Description: Concentration of a trace element in seawater. Does not include trace metals and metaloids. Refer to dataset for element name and units.Periodic Table

PI-supplied Description: Longitude according to the event log; West is negative; General Description: longitude, in decimal degrees, East is positive, negative denotes West; Reported in some datsets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest.

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: <p>Samples analyzed for acid-volatile sulfides (AVS) were collected on McLane pumps suspended from a trace metal wire (Hytrel-jacketed Vectran). Pumps filtered for four hours, flowing first over a 51-µm polyester pre-filter, then over paired 0.8-µm pore-size, 142-mm Supor polyethersulfone filters. A small portion of the top Supor filter, representing ~2% of the filter area (0.8-51 µm size-fraction material), was sub-sectioned into polyethylene vials and frozen at -85˚C until shipboard AVS analysis, described below. Filter blanks were held within identical filter housings and submerged on one of the deeper pumps on each cast, but were not actively filtered through. Blanks were handled identically to samples during processing, which was conducted in a HEPA-filtered environment using trace metal procedures.</p><p>Particulate elemental samples were collected using McLane in situ pumps (P. Lam, UCSC) with splits (section) from a 0.8 µm Supor filter processed immediately in a N<sub>2</sub>-purged glove bag after collection and pump recovery; filter splits were placed and sealed in Tedlar bags and stored at -80°C until analysis. Particulate elemental selenium concentrations were determined using a sulfite leach following Velinsky and Cutter (1990) and analyzed like selenite+selenate following Cutter (1978).&nbsp; Precision was ca. 10% RSD (n=3).&nbsp;</p><p><strong>References:</strong>&nbsp;</p><p>Cutter, Gregory. "Species Determination of Selenium in Natural Waters." <em>Analytica Chimica Acta </em>98 (1978): 59-66.&nbsp;<a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0003-2670(01)83238-4" id="doi-value" style="box-sizing: inherit; color: rgb(49, 108, 157); text-decoration: none; background-color: transparent;" target="_blank" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier">doi:10.1016/S0003-2670(01)83238-4</a></p><p>Velinsky, D.J., and G.A. Cutter. "Determination of elemental selenium and pyrite-selenium in sediments." <em>Analytica Chimica Acta </em>235 (1990): 419-425. &nbsp;<a href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0003-2670(00)82102-9" id="doi-value" style="box-sizing: inherit; color: rgb(49, 108, 157); text-decoration: none; background-color: transparent;" target="_blank" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier">doi:10.1016/S0003-2670(00)82102-9</a></p><p>&nbsp;</p>

<p>Samples analyzed in triplicate and means computed. Standard additions of selenite were used for daily calibration on a representative sample and its slope applied to subsequent samples.</p><p>Determinations of acid-volatile sulfide (AVS) were made on-board ship and used the method of Cutter and Oatts (Cutter and Oatts, 1987) that includes acidification, gas stripping and cryogenic trapping/preconcentration of the generated hydrogen sulfide. In this case, the filter slice was placed in a glass stripping vessel, 10 mL of deionized water added, and the stripper purged with He. The cryogenic trap was then immersed in liquid nitrogen, 10mL of 1M HCl added through a septum in the stripping vessel and the evolved and trapped hydrogen sulfide was then quantified using the gas chromatography/flame photometric detection method of Radford-Knoery and Cutter (Radford-Knoery and Cutter, 1993). The system was calibrated with hydrogen sulfide from a permeation tube (calibrated diffusion rate) and assuming a filtration volume of at least 5L (median sample volume: 7.9L), the detection limit was 0.2 pmol/L. It should be noted that AVS determined by this method includes monosulfides of iron, zinc, and nickel, but not those with copper or mercury, or mixed oxidation state sulfides such as greigite or pyrite (Cutter and Oatts, 1987; Radford-Knoery and Cutter, 1993).</p><p><strong>References:</strong>&nbsp;</p><p>Cutter, G.A. and T.J. Oatts. 1987. Determination of dissolved sulfide and sedimentary sulfur speciation using gas chromatography-photoionization detection.&nbsp; Anal. Chem. 59: 717-721.&nbsp;<strong>DOI:&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://doi.org/10.1021/ac00132a008">10.1021/ac00132a008</a></p><p>Radford-Knoery, J. and G.A. Cutter. 1993. Determination of carbonyl sulfide and hydrogen&nbsp;sulfide species in natural waters using specialized collection procedures and gas chromatography with flame photometric detection. Anal. Chem., 65: 976-982.&nbsp;<strong>DOI:&nbsp;</strong><a href="http://doi.org/10.1021/ac00056a005">10.1021/ac00056a005</a></p>

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: PI Supplied Instrument Name: McLane pumps PI Supplied Instrument Description:In the data, McLane pumps are called "McL-Prof." Instrument Name: McLane Pump Instrument Short Name:McLane Pump Instrument Description: McLane pumps sample large volumes of seawater at depth. They are attached to a wire and lowered to different depths in the ocean. As the water is pumped through the filter, particles suspended in the ocean are collected on the filters. The pumps are then retrieved and the contents of the filters are analyzed in a lab.

PI Supplied Instrument Name: Gas chromatograph PI Supplied Instrument Description:Gas chromatograph/flame photometric ionizer Instrument Name: Gas Chromatograph Instrument Short Name:Gas Chromatograph Instrument Description: Instrument separating gases, volatile substances, or substances dissolved in a volatile solvent by transporting an inert gas through a column packed with a sorbent to a detector for assay. (from SeaDataNet, BODC) Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/LAB02/
